articles.title: Crimean War
articles.context: Greece played a peripheral role in the war. When Russia attacked the Ottoman Empire in 1853, King Otto of Greece saw an opportunity to expand North and South into Ottoman areas that had large Greek Christian majorities. However, Greece did not coordinate its plans with Russia, did not declare war, and received no outside military or financial support. Greece, an Orthodox nation, had considerable support in Russia, but the Russian government decided it was too dangerous to help Greece expand its holdings.:32â€“40 When the Russians invaded the Principalities, the Ottoman forces were tied down so Greece invaded Thessaly and Epirus. To block further Greek moves, the British and French occupied the main Greek port at Piraeus from April 1854 to February 1857, and effectively neutralized the Greek army. Greeks, gambling on a Russian victory, incited the large-scale Epirus Revolt of 1854 as well as uprisings in Crete. The insurrections were failures that were easily crushed by the Ottoman army. Greece was not invited to the peace conference and made no gains out of the war.:139 The frustrated Greek leadership blamed the King for failing to take advantage of the situation; his popularity plunged and he was later forced to abdicate.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and produce a very long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
Crimean War
Greece played a peripheral role in the war. When Russia attacked the Ottoman Empire in 1853, King Otto of Greece saw an opportunity to expand North and South into Ottoman areas that had large Greek Christian majorities. However, Greece did not coordinate its plans with Russia, did not declare war, and received no outside military or financial support. Greece, an Orthodox nation, had considerable support in Russia, but the Russian government decided it was too dangerous to help Greece expand its holdings.:32â€“40 When the Russians invaded the Principalities, the Ottoman forces were tied down so Greece invaded Thessaly and Epirus. To block further Greek moves, the British and French occupied the main Greek port at Piraeus from April 1854 to February 1857, and effectively neutralized the Greek army. Greeks, gambling on a Russian victory, incited the large-scale Epirus Revolt of 1854 as well as uprisings in Crete. The insurrections were failures that were easily crushed by the Ottoman army. Greece was not invited to the peace conference and made no gains out of the war.:139 The frustrated Greek leadership blamed the King for failing to take advantage of the situation; his popularity plunged and he was later forced to abdicate.

articles.title: Financial crisis of 2007%E2%80%9308
articles.context: In testimony before the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation on June 3, 2008, former director of the CFTC Division of Trading & Markets (responsible for enforcement) Michael Greenberger specifically named the Atlanta-based IntercontinentalExchange, founded by Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and BP as playing a key role in speculative run-up of oil futures prices traded off the regulated futures exchanges in London and New York. However, the IntercontinentalExchange (ICE) had been regulated by both European and U.S. authorities since its purchase of the International Petroleum Exchange in 2001. Mr Greenberger was later corrected on this matter.

Financial crisis of 2007%E2%80%9308
In testimony before the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation on June 3, 2008, former director of the CFTC Division of Trading & Markets (responsible for enforcement) Michael Greenberger specifically named the Atlanta-based IntercontinentalExchange, founded by Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and BP as playing a key role in speculative run-up of oil futures prices traded off the regulated futures exchanges in London and New York. Mr Greenberger was later corrected on this matter.

articles.title: History of India
articles.context: The 7th and 6th centuries BC witnessed the composition of the earliest Upanishads. Upanishads form the theoretical basis of classical Hinduism and are known as Vedanta (conclusion of the Vedas). The older Upanishads launched attacks of increasing intensity on the ritual. Anyone who worships a divinity other than the Self is called a domestic animal of the gods in the Brihadaranyaka Upanishad. The Mundaka launches the most scathing attack on the ritual by comparing those who value sacrifice with an unsafe boat that is endlessly overtaken by old age and death.

3. The older Upanishads began attacking the ritual, indicating a shift in religious practices within Hinduism during that period.

6. This critique of rituals might signify a move towards a more spiritual and introspective form of Hinduism, focusing on personal self-realization rather than external rituals.
7. The development of the Upanishads represents a turning point in the history of Hindu philosophy, as it marks the transition from a ritualistic to a more introspective approach.

9. The critique of rituals in the Upanishads suggests that Hinduism may have experienced a period of internal reflection and questioning about the meaning of life and the role of rituals in spiritual practice.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and produce a very long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
History of India
The 7th and 6th centuries BC witnessed the composition of the earliest Upanishads. Upanishads form the theoretical basis of classical Hinduism and are known as Vedanta (conclusion of the Vedas). The older Upanishads launched attacks of increasing intensity on the ritual. Anyone who worships a divinity other than the Self is called a domestic animal of the gods in the Brihadaranyaka Upanishad. The Mundaka launches the most scathing attack on the ritual by comparing those who value sacrifice with an unsafe boat that is endlessly overtaken by old age and death.

Implications:

articles.title: Memory
articles.context: Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment, it is not the case. The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very dynamic and comprise distinct phases covering a time window from seconds to even a lifetime. In fact, research has revealed that our memories are constructed. People can construct their memories when they encode them and/or when they recall them. To illustrate, consider a classic study conducted by Elizabeth Loftus and John Palmer (1974) in which people were instructed to watch a film of a traffic accident and then asked about what they saw. The researchers found that the people who were asked, "How fast were the cars going when they smashed into each other?" gave higher estimates than those who were asked, "How fast were the cars going when they hit each other?" Furthermore, when asked a week later whether they have seen broken glass in the film, those who had been asked the question with smashed were twice more likely to report that they have seen broken glass than those who had been asked the question with hit. There was no broken glass depicted in the film. Thus, the wording of the questions distorted viewersâ€™ memories of the event. Importantly, the wording of the question led people to construct different memories of the event â€“ those who were asked the question with smashed recalled a more serious car accident than they had actually seen. The findings of this experiment were replicated around the world, and researchers consistently demonstrated that when people were provided with misleading information they tended to misremember, a phenomenon known as the misinformation effect.

completions.text:
1. Memory is not a direct recording of experiences, but rather a construction process.
2. Our memories can be dynamically influenced by various factors.
3. The induction and maintenance of memory involve distinct phases.
4. Memory construction can occur during both encoding and recall processes.
5. The wording of questions or information can affect how we remember events.
6. People's memories can be distorted through the provision of misleading information.
7. The misinformation effect highlights the susceptibility of memories to external influences.
8. The word choice and phrasing of information can impact the accuracy of one's recollections.
9. Misinformation can create a false memory, leading individuals to believe they experienced something that did not happen.
10. The construction of memories can have significant consequences on how we perceive and understand events.
11. Our understanding and interpretation of past events may be subject to biases introduced by the way information is presented.
12. Misleading information can contribute to the creation of false memories, which may persist even if we know the information is incorrect.
13. The malleability of memory raises questions about the reliability of eyewitness testimonies and the role of cross-examination.
14. The construction of memories can have implications in various fields, such as law, psychology, and education, where accurate recall is crucial.
15. The finding that people may misremember an event when asked certain questions can lead to the need for carefully designed surveys and studies.
16. The phenomenon of memory construction suggests the importance of considering the context and potential biases when studying human memory.
17. Misleading information can lead to incorrect conclusions and can have negative consequences in decision-making processes.
18. The construction of memories can have psychological implications, as individuals may rely on their memories to form their identity and beliefs.
19. Research into memory construction can contribute to a deeper understanding of human cognition and the processes underlying memory formation.
20. The misinformation effect has implications for various practical applications, such as ensuring accurate information in legal proceedings or improving educational materials.
21. The findings of this experiment emphasize the need for careful consideration and transparency when sharing or manipulating information.
22. The malleability of memory highlights the importance of fostering critical thinking and skepticism when encountering new information.
23. Misleading information can have implications for mental health and well-being, as individuals may become increasingly susceptible to false beliefs and conspiracy theories.
24. The construction of memories can affect social interactions, as individuals' recollections of past events may shape their perceptions and relationships with others.
25. The findings of this study have implications for memory-enhancing techniques and interventions aimed at improving recall accuracy.
26. The misinformation effect can have significant consequences in the field of journalism, where accurate reporting is essential.
27. The malleability of memory suggests that individuals should be cautious when accepting and spreading information from unreliable sources.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and produce a very long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
Memory
Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment, it is not the case. The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very dynamic and comprise distinct phases covering a time window from seconds to even a lifetime. In fact, research has revealed that our memories are constructed. People can construct their memories when they encode them and/or when they recall them. To illustrate, consider a classic study conducted by Elizabeth Loftus and John Palmer (1974) in which people were instructed to watch a film of a traffic accident and then asked about what they saw. The researchers found that the people who were asked, "How fast were the cars going when they smashed into each other?" gave higher estimates than those who were asked, "How fast were the cars going when they hit each other?" Furthermore, when asked a week later whether they have seen broken glass in the film, those who had been asked the question with smashed were twice more likely to report that they have seen broken glass than those who had been asked the question with hit. There was no broken glass depicted in the film. Thus, the wording of the questions distorted viewersâ€™ memories of the event. Importantly, the wording of the question led people to construct different memories of the event â€“ those who were asked the question with smashed recalled a more serious car accident than they had actually seen. The findings of this experiment were replicated around the world, and researchers consistently demonstrated that when people were provided with misleading information they tended to misremember, a phenomenon known as the misinformation effect.

Implications:

articles.title: Antarctica
articles.context: Although coal, hydrocarbons, iron ore, platinum, copper, chromium, nickel, gold and other minerals have been found, they have not been in large enough quantities to exploit. The 1991 Protocol on Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty also restricts a struggle for resources. In 1998, a compromise agreement was reached to place an indefinite ban on mining, to be reviewed in 2048, further limiting economic development and exploitation. The primary economic activity is the capture and offshore trading of fish. Antarctic fisheries in 2000â€“01 reported landing 112,934 tonnes.

articles.title: Neptune
articles.context: Claiming the right to name his discovery, Le Verrier quickly proposed the name Neptune for this new planet, though falsely stating that this had been officially approved by the French Bureau des Longitudes. In October, he sought to name the planet Le Verrier, after himself, and he had loyal support in this from the observatory director, FranÃ§ois Arago. This suggestion met with stiff resistance outside France. French almanacs quickly reintroduced the name Herschel for Uranus, after that planet's discoverer Sir William Herschel, and Leverrier for the new planet.

articles.context: Four separate and distinct state universities are located in Houston. The University of Houston is a nationally recognized Tier One research university, and is the flagship institution of the University of Houston System. The third-largest university in Texas, the University of Houston has nearly 40,000 students on its 667-acre campus in southeast Houston. The University of Houstonâ€“Clear Lake and the University of Houstonâ€“Downtown are stand-alone universities; they are not branch campuses of the University of Houston. Located in the historic community of Third Ward is Texas Southern University, one of the largest historically black colleges and universities in the United States.

articles.title: Mexico City
articles.context: Mexico City, being the seat of the powers of the Union, did not belong to any particular state but to all. Therefore, it was the president, representing the federation, who used to designate the head of government of the Federal District, a position which is sometimes presented outside Mexico as the "Mayor" of Mexico City.[citation needed] In the 1980s, given the dramatic increase in population of the previous decades, the inherent political inconsistencies of the system, as well as the dissatisfaction with the inadequate response of the federal government after the 1985 earthquake, residents began to request political and administrative autonomy to manage their local affairs.[citation needed] Some political groups even proposed that the Federal District be converted into the 32nd state of the federation.

Let's read the following passage and produce a very long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
Mexico City
Mexico City, being the seat of the powers of the Union, did not belong to any particular state but to all. Therefore, it was the president, representing the federation, who used to designate the head of government of the Federal District, a position which is sometimes presented outside Mexico as the "Mayor" of Mexico City.[citation needed] In the 1980s, given the dramatic increase in population of the previous decades, the inherent political inconsistencies of the system, as well as the dissatisfaction with the inadequate response of the federal government after the 1985 earthquake, residents began to request political and administrative autonomy to manage their local affairs.[citation needed] Some political groups even proposed that the Federal District be converted into the 32nd state of the federation.

articles.title: Brain
articles.context: Once a neuron is in place, it extends dendrites and an axon into the area around it. Axons, because they commonly extend a great distance from the cell body and need to reach specific targets, grow in a particularly complex way. The tip of a growing axon consists of a blob of protoplasm called a growth cone, studded with chemical receptors. These receptors sense the local environment, causing the growth cone to be attracted or repelled by various cellular elements, and thus to be pulled in a particular direction at each point along its path. The result of this pathfinding process is that the growth cone navigates through the brain until it reaches its destination area, where other chemical cues cause it to begin generating synapses. Considering the entire brain, thousands of genes create products that influence axonal pathfinding.

completions.text:

2. The brain is composed of thousands of neurons, each with dendrites and an axon extending into the area around it.
3. Axons, in particular, grow in a complex way, requiring guidance from chemical receptors.
4. The growth cone, found at the tip of a growing axon, is responsible for navigating the environment in response to various chemical cues.
5. The growth cone is studded with chemical receptors, which allow it to sense the local environment and adjust its path accordingly.
6. The axon's pathfinding process involves a combination of attraction and repulsion by different cellular elements.
7. Successful navigation of the axon's path involves reaching a destination area, where other chemical cues cause the growth cone to begin generating synapses.
8. The overall brain function is influenced by the growth and development of thousands of genes, each producing products that affect axonal pathfinding.
9. These products include chemicals that act as receptors, guiding the growth cone through the brain.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and produce a very long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
Brain
Once a neuron is in place, it extends dendrites and an axon into the area around it. Axons, because they commonly extend a great distance from the cell body and need to reach specific targets, grow in a particularly complex way. The tip of a growing axon consists of a blob of protoplasm called a growth cone, studded with chemical receptors. These receptors sense the local environment, causing the growth cone to be attracted or repelled by various cellular elements, and thus to be pulled in a particular direction at each point along its path. The result of this pathfinding process is that the growth cone navigates through the brain until it reaches its destination area, where other chemical cues cause it to begin generating synapses. Considering the entire brain, thousands of genes create products that influence axonal pathfinding.

articles.title: Capital punishment in the United States
articles.context: James Liebman, a professor of law at Columbia Law School, stated in 1996 that his study found that when habeas corpus petitions in death penalty cases were traced from conviction to completion of the case that there was "a 40 percent success rate in all capital cases from 1978 to 1995." Similarly, a study by Ronald Tabak in a law review article puts the success rate in habeas corpus cases involving death row inmates even higher, finding that between "1976 and 1991, approximately 47 percent of the habeas petitions filed by death row inmates were granted." The different numbers are largely definitional, rather than substantive. Freedam's statistics looks at the percentage of all death penalty cases reversed, while the others look only at cases not reversed prior to habeas corpus review.

Capital punishment in the United States

Similarly, a study by Ronald Tabak in a law review article puts the success rate in habeas corpus cases involving death row inmates even higher, finding that between "1976 and 1991, approximately 47 percent of the habeas petitions filed by death row inmates were granted." The different numbers are largely definitional, rather than substantive. Freedam's statistics looks at the percentage of all death penalty cases reversed, while the others look only at cases not reversed prior to habeas corpus review.

articles.title: Boston
articles.context: The TD Garden, formerly called the FleetCenter and built to replace the old, since-demolished Boston Garden, is adjoined to North Station and is the home of two major league teams: the Boston Bruins of the National Hockey League and the Boston Celtics of the National Basketball Association. The arena seats 18,624 for basketball games and 17,565 for ice hockey games. The Bruins were the first American member of the National Hockey League and an Original Six franchise. The Boston Celtics were founding members of the Basketball Association of America, one of the two leagues that merged to form the NBA. The Celtics have the distinction of having won more championships than any other NBA team, with seventeen.

articles.context: Secretory diarrhea means that there is an increase in the active secretion, or there is an inhibition of absorption. There is little to no structural damage. The most common cause of this type of diarrhea is a cholera toxin that stimulates the secretion of anions, especially chloride ions. Therefore, to maintain a charge balance in the lumen, sodium is carried with it, along with water. In this type of diarrhea intestinal fluid secretion is isotonic with plasma even during fasting. It continues even when there is no oral food intake.

articles.title: Electric motor
articles.context: An advantage of the universal motor is that AC supplies may be used on motors which have some characteristics more common in DC motors, specifically high starting torque and very compact design if high running speeds are used. The negative aspect is the maintenance and short life problems caused by the commutator. Such motors are used in devices such as food mixers and power tools which are used only intermittently, and often have high starting-torque demands. Multiple taps on the field coil provide (imprecise) stepped speed control. Household blenders that advertise many speeds frequently combine a field coil with several taps and a diode that can be inserted in series with the motor (causing the motor to run on half-wave rectified AC). Universal motors also lend themselves to electronic speed control and, as such, are an ideal choice for devices like domestic washing machines. The motor can be used to agitate the drum (both forwards and in reverse) by switching the field winding with respect to the armature.

questions.baseline_answer: Stepped speed control is achieved by using a variable frequency drive (VFD) to adjust the frequency of the electrical power supplied to the motor. This changes the speed of the motor in discrete steps, allowing for precise control over the motor's speed.
questions.adapter_answer: Step motors are used in devices like disk drives and printers, where rapid changes in speed are required. The use of field coils allows for easy reversal of the motor. However, the use of stepped control (common in devices like disk drives) limits the motor's usefulness in applications requiring smooth speed control.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and produce a very long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
Electric motor
An advantage of the universal motor is that AC supplies may be used on motors which have some characteristics more common in DC motors, specifically high starting torque and very compact design if high running speeds are used. The negative aspect is the maintenance and short life problems caused by the commutator. Such motors are used in devices such as food mixers and power tools which are used only intermittently, and often have high starting-torque demands. Multiple taps on the field coil provide (imprecise) stepped speed control. Household blenders that advertise many speeds frequently combine a field coil with several taps and a diode that can be inserted in series with the motor (causing the motor to run on half-wave rectified AC). Universal motors also lend themselves to electronic speed control and, as such, are an ideal choice for devices like domestic washing machines. The motor can be used to agitate the drum (both forwards and in reverse) by switching the field winding with respect to the armature.

articles.title: Dwight D. Eisenhower
articles.context: His parents set aside specific times at breakfast and at dinner for daily family Bible reading. Chores were regularly assigned and rotated among all the children, and misbehavior was met with unequivocal discipline, usually from David. His mother, previously a member (with David) of the River Brethren sect of the Mennonites, joined the International Bible Students Association, later known as Jehovah's Witnesses. The Eisenhower home served as the local meeting hall from 1896 to 1915, though Eisenhower never joined the International Bible Students. His later decision to attend West Point saddened his mother, who felt that warfare was "rather wicked," but she did not overrule him. While speaking of himself in 1948, Eisenhower said he was "one of the most deeply religious men I know" though unattached to any "sect or organization". He was baptized in the Presbyterian Church in 1953.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and produce a very long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
Dwight D. Eisenhower
His parents set aside specific times at breakfast and at dinner for daily family Bible reading. Chores were regularly assigned and rotated among all the children, and misbehavior was met with unequivocal discipline, usually from David. His mother, previously a member (with David) of the River Brethren sect of the Mennonites, joined the International Bible Students Association, later known as Jehovah's Witnesses. The Eisenhower home served as the local meeting hall from 1896 to 1915, though Eisenhower never joined the International Bible Students. His later decision to attend West Point saddened his mother, who felt that warfare was "rather wicked," but she did not overrule him. While speaking of himself in 1948, Eisenhower said he was "one of the most deeply religious men I know" though unattached to any "sect or organization". He was baptized in the Presbyterian Church in 1953.

Implications:

articles.title: FrÃ©dÃ©ric Chopin
articles.context: Chopin arrived in Paris in late September 1831; he would never return to Poland, thus becoming one of many expatriates of the Polish Great Emigration. In France he used the French versions of his given names, and after receiving French citizenship in 1835, he travelled on a French passport. However, Chopin remained close to his fellow Poles in exile as friends and confidants and he never felt fully comfortable speaking French. Chopin's biographer Adam Zamoyski writes that he never considered himself to be French, despite his father's French origins, and always saw himself as a Pole.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and produce a very long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
FrÃ©dÃ©ric Chopin
Chopin arrived in Paris in late September 1831; he would never return to Poland, thus becoming one of many expatriates of the Polish Great Emigration. In France he used the French versions of his given names, and after receiving French citizenship in 1835, he travelled on a French passport. However, Chopin remained close to his fellow Poles in exile as friends and confidants and he never felt fully comfortable speaking French. Chopin's biographer Adam Zamoyski writes that he never considered himself to be French, despite his father's French origins, and always saw himself as a Pole.

Implications:

articles.title: Pacific War
articles.context: The Battle of Leyte Gulf was arguably the largest naval battle in history and was the largest naval battle of World War II. It was a series of four distinct engagements fought off the Philippine island of Leyte from 23 to 26 October 1944. Leyte Gulf featured the largest battleships ever built, was the last time in history that battleships engaged each other, and was also notable as the first time that kamikaze aircraft were used. Allied victory in the Philippine Sea established Allied air and sea superiority in the western Pacific. Nimitz favored blockading the Philippines and landing on Formosa. This would give the Allies control of the sea routes to Japan from southern Asia, cutting off substantial Japanese garrisons. MacArthur favored an invasion of the Philippines, which also lay across the supply lines to Japan. Roosevelt adjudicated in favor of the Philippines. Meanwhile, Japanese Combined Fleet Chief Toyoda Soemu prepared four plans to cover all Allied offensive scenarios. On 12 October Nimitz launched a carrier raid against Formosa to make sure that planes based there could not intervene in the landings on Leyte. Toyoda put Plan Sho-2 into effect, launching a series of air attacks against the U.S. carriers. However the Japanese lost 600 planes in three days, leaving them without air cover.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and produce a very long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
Pacific War
The Battle of Leyte Gulf was arguably the largest naval battle in history and was the largest naval battle of World War II. It was a series of four distinct engagements fought off the Philippine island of Leyte from 23 to 26 October 1944. Leyte Gulf featured the largest battleships ever built, was the last time in history that battleships engaged each other, and was also notable as the first time that kamikaze aircraft were used. Allied victory in the Philippine Sea established Allied air and sea superiority in the western Pacific. Nimitz favored blockading the Philippines and landing on Formosa. This would give the Allies control of the sea routes to Japan from southern Asia, cutting off substantial Japanese garrisons. MacArthur favored an invasion of the Philippines, which also lay across the supply lines to Japan. Roosevelt adjudicated in favor of the Philippines. Meanwhile, Japanese Combined Fleet Chief Toyoda Soemu prepared four plans to cover all Allied offensive scenarios. On 12 October Nimitz launched a carrier raid against Formosa to make sure that planes based there could not intervene in the landings on Leyte. Toyoda put Plan Sho-2 into effect, launching a series of air attacks against the U.S. carriers. However the Japanese lost 600 planes in three days, leaving them without air cover.

articles.context: In a June 2008 speech, President and CEO of the New York Federal Reserve Bank Timothy Geithnerâ€”who in 2009 became Secretary of the United States Treasuryâ€”placed significant blame for the freezing of credit markets on a "run" on the entities in the "parallel" banking system, also called the shadow banking system. These entities became critical to the credit markets underpinning the financial system, but were not subject to the same regulatory controls. Further, these entities were vulnerable because of maturity mismatch, meaning that they borrowed short-term in liquid markets to purchase long-term, illiquid and risky assets. This meant that disruptions in credit markets would make them subject to rapid deleveraging, selling their long-term assets at depressed prices. He described the significance of these entities:

articles.title: Tuberculosis
articles.context: In 15â€“20% of active cases, the infection spreads outside the lungs, causing other kinds of TB. These are collectively denoted as "extrapulmonary tuberculosis". Extrapulmonary TB occurs more commonly in immunosuppressed persons and young children. In those with HIV, this occurs in more than 50% of cases. Notable extrapulmonary infection sites include the pleura (in tuberculous pleurisy), the central nervous system (in tuberculous meningitis), the lymphatic system (in scrofula of the neck), the genitourinary system (in urogenital tuberculosis), and the bones and joints (in Pott disease of the spine), among others. When it spreads to the bones, it is also known as "osseous tuberculosis", a form of osteomyelitis. Sometimes, bursting of a tubercular abscess through skin results in tuberculous ulcer. An ulcer originating from nearby infected lymph nodes is painless, slowly enlarging and has an appearance of "wash leather". A potentially more serious, widespread form of TB is called "disseminated tuberculosis", also known as miliary tuberculosis. Miliary TB makes up about 10% of extrapulmonary cases.

completions.text:
1. Extrapulmonary tuberculosis occurs in 15-20% of active cases.
2. Extrapulmonary TB is more common in immunosuppressed persons and young children.
3. In individuals with HIV, extrapulmonary TB occurs in more than 50% of cases.
4. The most common sites for extrapulmonary TB are the pleura (in tuberculous pleurisy), the central nervous system (in tuberculous meningitis), the lymphatic system (in scrofula of the neck), the genitourinary system (in urogenital tuberculosis), and the bones and joints (in Pott disease of the spine).
5. The spread of TB beyond the lungs results in widespread infection known as disseminated tuberculosis or miliary tuberculosis.
6. Disseminated TB makes up about 10% of extrapulmonary TB cases.
7. Tuberculous ulcers are caused by the bursting of a tubercular abscess through the skin.
8. Tuberculous ulcers appear similar to "wash leather" due to their painless and slowly enlarging nature.
9. In severe cases, TB can spread through the bloodstream, affecting other organs and systems in the body.
10. The presence of extrapulmonary TB often requires a different treatment approach than pulmonary TB.
11. Pott disease is a specific form of bone and joint tuberculosis affecting the spine.
12. Urogenital tuberculosis can lead to complications if left untreated, such as infertility or urinary tract blockage.
13. Treatment of extrapulmonary TB may require a combination of medications to target the specific site of infection.
14. Identification and treatment of extrapulmonary TB is crucial to prevent its spread to other parts of the body and to prevent complications.
15. TB can affect various organs and systems, emphasizing the importance of early diagnosis and appropriate management to minimize the impact on overall health.
16. There is a need for better surveillance and detection methods for extrapulmonary TB to improve the management of the disease.
17. Prevention and control of extrapulmonary TB should be a priority in high-risk populations, such as individuals with HIV, young children, and those with compromised immune systems.
18. Research into the specific mechanisms of extrapulmonary TB can lead to the development of new diagnostic tools and treatment strategies.
19. Public awareness and education about the risks and symptoms of extrapulmonary TB are essential for early detection and prompt intervention.
20. The long-lasting effects of extrapulmonary TB highlight the need for continuous follow-up care and support for affected individuals.

Please generate a list of implications based on the above content.

1. The estimated burden of tuberculosis is likely underestimated by 30-40% due to undiagnosed and underreported cases.
2. The global incidence of tuberculosis is expected to remain stable in the future, with some regions experiencing a decline and others an increase.
3. Various estimates for the annual incidence of tuberculosis worldwide differ depending on the source and methodology used.
4. The increase in tuberculosis cases in 2007 may have been influenced by improved case detection and reporting.
5. Differences in the incidence of tuberculosis across countries may be influenced by varying socioeconomic factors, such as living conditions and access to healthcare.
6. The analysis of data from the WHO and other sources can provide valuable insights into the prevalence and burden of tuberculosis in different regions and populations.
7. The rise of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is a concerning trend that needs to be addressed to prevent further spread and worsening of the disease.
8. The presence of cavities and extensive lesions in MDR-TB cases indicates a more severe and aggressive form of the disease.
9. The effective management of MDR-TB requires appropriate testing, treatment, and adherence to ensure successful outcomes and prevent drug resistance.
10. The guidelines for the management of MDR-TB and extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB) should be revised to reflect the changing epidemiology and treatment options.
11. Surveillance and monitoring of tuberculosis cases, including drug-resistant cases, are crucial to inform public health policies and interventions.
12. The development of new diagnostic tools and treatment strategies is necessary to improve the management and control of tuberculosis, particularly in resource-limited settings.
13. Patient care guidelines should be regularly updated to reflect the latest evidence-based recommendations for the diagnosis, treatment, and management of tuberculosis.
14. The elimination of tuberculosis as a public health threat requires a comprehensive and sustained global effort involving all stakeholders, including governments, healthcare providers, researchers, and affected communities.
15. Addressing the social determinants of health, such as poverty, poor sanitation, and inadequate healthcare infrastructure, is essential for reducing the incidence and prevalence of tuberculosis.
16. The integration of tuberculosis control programs with other health interventions, such as HIV/AIDS and immunization programs, can enhance the overall effectiveness of public health initiatives.

Notable sites of extrapulmonary TB infection include the pleura (leading to tuberculous pleurisy), central nervous system (causing tuberculous meningitis), lymphatic system (leading to scrofula of the neck), genitourinary system (resulting in urogenital tuberculosis), and bones and joints (causing Pott disease of the spine).

8. TB can result in the formation of tuberculous ulcers, which are painless, slowly enlarging, and have a "wash leather" appearance.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and produce a very long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
Tuberculosis
In 15â€“20% of active cases, the infection spreads outside the lungs, causing other kinds of TB. These are collectively denoted as "extrapulmonary tuberculosis". Extrapulmonary TB occurs more commonly in immunosuppressed persons and young children. In those with HIV, this occurs in more than 50% of cases. Notable extrapulmonary infection sites include the pleura (in tuberculous pleurisy), the central nervous system (in tuberculous meningitis), the lymphatic system (in scrofula of the neck), the genitourinary system (in urogenital tuberculosis), and the bones and joints (in Pott disease of the spine), among others. When it spreads to the bones, it is also known as "osseous tuberculosis", a form of osteomyelitis. Sometimes, bursting of a tubercular abscess through skin results in tuberculous ulcer. An ulcer originating from nearby infected lymph nodes is painless, slowly enlarging and has an appearance of "wash leather". A potentially more serious, widespread form of TB is called "disseminated tuberculosis", also known as miliary tuberculosis. Miliary TB makes up about 10% of extrapulmonary cases.

articles.context: In the Paris Agreements of 23 October 1954, France offered to establish an independent "Saarland", under the auspices of the Western European Union (WEU), but on 23 October 1955 in the Saar Statute referendum the Saar electorate rejected this plan by 67.7% to 32.3% (out of a 96.5% turnout: 423,434 against, 201,975 for) despite the public support of Federal German Chancellor Konrad Adenauer for the plan. The rejection of the plan by the Saarlanders was interpreted as support for the Saar to join the Federal Republic of Germany.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and produce a very long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
States of Germany
In the Paris Agreements of 23 October 1954, France offered to establish an independent "Saarland", under the auspices of the Western European Union (WEU), but on 23 October 1955 in the Saar Statute referendum the Saar electorate rejected this plan by 67.7% to 32.3% (out of a 96.5% turnout: 423,434 against, 201,975 for) despite the public support of Federal German Chancellor Konrad Adenauer for the plan. The rejection of the plan by the Saarlanders was interpreted as support for the Saar to join the Federal Republic of Germany.

articles.title: Pope Paul VI
articles.context: In 1916, he entered the seminary to become a Roman Catholic priest. He was ordained priest on 29 May 1920 in Brescia and celebrated his first Holy Mass in Brescia in the Basilica of Santa Maria delle Grazie. Montini concluded his studies in Milan with a doctorate in Canon Law in the same year. Afterwards he studied at the Gregorian University, the University of Rome La Sapienza and, at the request of Giuseppe Pizzardo at the Accademia dei Nobili Ecclesiastici. At the age of twenty-five, again at the request of Giuseppe Pizzardo, Montini entered the Secretariat of State in 1922, where he worked under Pizzardo together with Francesco Borgongini-Duca, Alfredo Ottaviani, Carlo Grano, Domenico Tardini and Francis Spellman. Consequently, he spent not a day as a parish priest. In 1925 he helped found the publishing house Morcelliana in Brescia, focused on promoting a 'Christian inspired culture'.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and produce a very long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
Pope Paul VI
In 1916, he entered the seminary to become a Roman Catholic priest. He was ordained priest on 29 May 1920 in Brescia and celebrated his first Holy Mass in Brescia in the Basilica of Santa Maria delle Grazie. Montini concluded his studies in Milan with a doctorate in Canon Law in the same year. Afterwards he studied at the Gregorian University, the University of Rome La Sapienza and, at the request of Giuseppe Pizzardo at the Accademia dei Nobili Ecclesiastici. At the age of twenty-five, again at the request of Giuseppe Pizzardo, Montini entered the Secretariat of State in 1922, where he worked under Pizzardo together with Francesco Borgongini-Duca, Alfredo Ottaviani, Carlo Grano, Domenico Tardini and Francis Spellman. Consequently, he spent not a day as a parish priest. In 1925 he helped found the publishing house Morcelliana in Brescia, focused on promoting a 'Christian inspired culture'.

Implications:

articles.context: The public sector effort continues with the goal to create a high-quality, draft genome sequence from reads generated by all sources. The public-sector effort has generated Sanger reads of BACs, fosmids, and plasmids as well as 454 reads. These later types of reads will be instrumental in assembling an initial draft of the D genome. In 2010, two companies (Monsanto and Illumina), completed enough Illumina sequencing to cover the D genome of G. raimondii about 50x. They announced that they would donate their raw reads to the public. This public relations effort gave them some recognition for sequencing the cotton genome. Once the D genome is assembled from all of this raw material, it will undoubtedly assist in the assembly of the AD genomes of cultivated varieties of cotton, but a lot of hard work remains.

Let's read the following passage and produce a very long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
Cotton
The public sector effort continues with the goal to create a high-quality, draft genome sequence from reads generated by all sources. The public-sector effort has generated Sanger reads of BACs, fosmids, and plasmids as well as 454 reads. These later types of reads will be instrumental in assembling an initial draft of the D genome. In 2010, two companies (Monsanto and Illumina), completed enough Illumina sequencing to cover the D genome of G. raimondii about 50x. They announced that they would donate their raw reads to the public. This public relations effort gave them some recognition for sequencing the cotton genome. Once the D genome is assembled from all of this raw material, it will undoubtedly assist in the assembly of the AD genomes of cultivated varieties of cotton, but a lot of hard work remains.

articles.title: Solar energy
articles.context: A solar chimney (or thermal chimney, in this context) is a passive solar ventilation system composed of a vertical shaft connecting the interior and exterior of a building. As the chimney warms, the air inside is heated causing an updraft that pulls air through the building. Performance can be improved by using glazing and thermal mass materials in a way that mimics greenhouses.

articles.title: Asthma
articles.context: The evidence for the effectiveness of measures to prevent the development of asthma is weak. Some show promise including: limiting smoke exposure both in utero and after delivery, breastfeeding, and increased exposure to daycare or large families but none are well supported enough to be recommended for this indication. Early pet exposure may be useful. Results from exposure to pets at other times are inconclusive and it is only recommended that pets be removed from the home if a person has allergic symptoms to said pet. Dietary restrictions during pregnancy or when breast feeding have not been found to be effective and thus are not recommended. Reducing or eliminating compounds known to sensitive people from the work place may be effective. It is not clear if annual influenza vaccinations effects the risk of exacerbations. Immunization; however, is recommended by the World Health Organization. Smoking bans are effective in decreasing exacerbations of asthma.

completions.text:
1. The effectiveness of measures to prevent the development of asthma is weak.
2. Some measures show promise, such as limiting smoke exposure, breastfeeding, and increased exposure to daycare or large families.
3. The evidence for the effectiveness of these measures is not strong enough to be recommended as preventative measures for asthma.
4. Early pet exposure may be useful in preventing asthma, but more research is needed to confirm this.
5. There is no clear evidence supporting the removal of pets from the home if someone has allergic symptoms to them.
6. Dietary restrictions during pregnancy or while breastfeeding have not been found to be effective in preventing asthma and are not recommended.
7. Reducing or eliminating known triggers in the work environment may be effective in managing asthma symptoms.
8. Annual influenza vaccinations have not been shown to significantly affect the risk of asthma exacerbations.
9. Smoking bans are effective in decreasing asthma exacerbations, supporting their implementation as a preventative measure.

Passage:
Asthma
The evidence for the effectiveness of measures to prevent the development of asthma is weak. Some show promise including: limiting smoke exposure both in utero and after delivery, breastfeeding, and increased exposure to daycare or large families but none are well supported enough to be recommended for this indication. Early pet exposure may be useful. Results from exposure to pets at other times are inconclusive and it is only recommended that pets be removed from the home if a person has allergic symptoms to said pet. Dietary restrictions during pregnancy or when breast feeding have not been found to be effective and thus are not recommended. Reducing or eliminating compounds known to sensitive people from the work place may be effective. It is not clear if annual influenza vaccinations effects the risk of exacerbations. Immunization; however, is recommended by the World Health Organization. Smoking bans are effective in decreasing exacerbations of asthma.

articles.title: North Carolina
articles.context: After secession, some North Carolinians refused to support the Confederacy. Some of the yeoman farmers in the state's mountains and western Piedmont region remained neutral during the Civil War, while some covertly supported the Union cause during the conflict. Approximately 2,000 North Carolinians from western North Carolina enlisted in the Union Army and fought for the North in the war. Two additional Union Army regiments were raised in the coastal areas of the state, which were occupied by Union forces in 1862 and 1863. Numerous slaves escaped to Union lines, where they became essentially free.

articles.title: Law of the United States
articles.context: Federal law and treaties, so long as they are in accordance with the Constitution, preempt conflicting state and territorial laws in the 50 U.S. states and in the territories. However, the scope of federal preemption is limited because the scope of federal power is not universal. In the dual-sovereign system of American federalism (actually tripartite because of the presence of Indian reservations), states are the plenary sovereigns, each with their own constitution, while the federal sovereign possesses only the limited supreme authority enumerated in the Constitution. Indeed, states may grant their citizens broader rights than the federal Constitution as long as they do not infringe on any federal constitutional rights. Thus, most U.S. law (especially the actual "living law" of contract, tort, property, criminal, and family law experienced by the majority of citizens on a day-to-day basis) consists primarily of state law, which can and does vary greatly from one state to the next.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and produce a very long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
Law of the United States
Federal law and treaties, so long as they are in accordance with the Constitution, preempt conflicting state and territorial laws in the 50 U.S. states and in the territories. However, the scope of federal preemption is limited because the scope of federal power is not universal. In the dual-sovereign system of American federalism (actually tripartite because of the presence of Indian reservations), states are the plenary sovereigns, each with their own constitution, while the federal sovereign possesses only the limited supreme authority enumerated in the Constitution. Indeed, states may grant their citizens broader rights than the federal Constitution as long as they do not infringe on any federal constitutional rights. Thus, most U.S. law (especially the actual "living law" of contract, tort, property, criminal, and family law experienced by the majority of citizens on a day-to-day basis) consists primarily of state law, which can and does vary greatly from one state to the next.

articles.context: Switzerland is one of the richest and wealthiest countries in the world. Switzerland ranks top or close to the top in several metrics of national performance, including government transparency, civil liberties, quality of life, economic competitiveness, and human development. It has the highest nominal wealth (financial and non-financial assets) per adult in the world according to Credit Suisse and the eighth-highest per capita gross domestic product on the IMF list. ZÃ¼rich and Geneva have each been ranked among the top cities with the highest quality of life in the world, with the former ranked 2nd globally, according to Mercer.

articles.title: Age of Enlightenment
articles.context: In Germany, practical reference works intended for the uneducated majority became popular in the 18th century. The Marperger Curieuses Natur-, Kunst-, Berg-, Gewerkund Handlungs-Lexicon (1712) explained terms that usefully described the trades and scientific and commercial education. Jablonksi Allgemeines Lexicon (1721) was better known than the Handlungs-Lexicon, and underscored technical subjects rather than scientific theory. For example, over five columns of text were dedicated to wine, while geometry and logic were allocated only twenty-two and seventeen lines, respectively. The first edition of the EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica (1771) was modelled along the same lines as the German lexicons.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and produce a very long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
Age of Enlightenment
In Germany, practical reference works intended for the uneducated majority became popular in the 18th century. The Marperger Curieuses Natur-, Kunst-, Berg-, Gewerkund Handlungs-Lexicon (1712) explained terms that usefully described the trades and scientific and commercial education. Jablonksi Allgemeines Lexicon (1721) was better known than the Handlungs-Lexicon, and underscored technical subjects rather than scientific theory. For example, over five columns of text were dedicated to wine, while geometry and logic were allocated only twenty-two and seventeen lines, respectively. The first edition of the EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica (1771) was modelled along the same lines as the German lexicons.

articles.title: PlayStation 3
articles.context: The console was first officially announced at E3 2005, and was released at the end of 2006. It was the first console to use Blu-ray Disc as its primary storage medium. The console was the first PlayStation to integrate social gaming services, included it being the first to introduce Sony's social gaming service, PlayStation Network, and its remote connectivity with PlayStation Portable and PlayStation Vita, being able to remote control the console from the devices. In September 2009, the Slim model of the PlayStation 3 was released, being lighter and thinner than the original version, which notably featured a redesigned logo and marketing design, as well as a minor start-up change in software. A Super Slim variation was then released in late 2012, further refining and redesigning the console. As of March 2016, PlayStation 3 has sold 85 million units worldwide. Its successor, the PlayStation 4, was released later in November 2013.

articles.title: Immunology
articles.context: The most well-known disease that affects the immune system itself is AIDS, an immunodeficiency characterized by the suppression of CD4+ ("helper") T cells, dendritic cells and macrophages by the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV).

completions.text:
1. AIDS is a disease caused by the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV).
2. AIDS affects the immune system by suppressing CD4+ T cells, dendritic cells, and macrophages.
3. T cells, dendritic cells, and macrophages are essential components of the immune system.
4. The suppression of these immune cells impairs the body's ability to fight off infections and diseases.
5. Individuals with AIDS are at a higher risk of developing various opportunistic infections and cancers due to a weakened immune system.
6. HIV primarily targets CD4+ T cells, leading to their depletion and a compromised immune response.
7. Without an adequate immune response, the body cannot effectively eliminate the HIV virus, leading to a chronic infection.
8. HIV infection can progress to AIDS if left untreated, resulting in a severe decline in immune function.
9. The suppression of dendritic cells and macrophages by HIV hampers the body's ability to present and process antigens, further weakening the immune system.
10. A weakened immune system increases the likelihood of autoimmune disorders and other immunological issues in individuals with AIDS.
11. Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is used to treat HIV, which can help slow down the progression of the disease and improve immune function.
12. ART helps in controlling the viral load of HIV, reducing the replication of the virus and protecting immune cells.
13. By restoring and maintaining immune function, ART can help alleviate some of the symptoms associated with AIDS and reduce the risk of opportunistic infections.
14. While ART can slow down the progression of AIDS, it cannot cure the disease completely, and the virus remains latent in the body's cells.
15. Patients with HIV and AIDS require regular medical monitoring to manage their condition and prevent complications.
16. Antibiotic prophylaxis is often recommended for individuals with AIDS to prevent opportunistic infections.
17. Early diagnosis and treatment of HIV and AIDS can significantly improve the quality and longevity of life for infected individuals.
18. Public health initiatives are crucial in controlling the spread of HIV and AIDS, including education, testing, and access to ART.
19. The development of vaccines against HIV is an ongoing area of research with the aim of preventing HIV infection and its progression to AIDS.
20. The emergence of drug-resistant HIV strains poses a challenge in the treatment of AIDS, necessitating continued efforts in developing new antiretroviral medications.

articles.title: Geological history of Earth
articles.context: The Devonian spanned roughly from 419 to 359 Ma. The period was a time of great tectonic activity, as Laurasia and Gondwana drew closer together. The continent Euramerica (or Laurussia) was created in the early Devonian by the collision of Laurentia and Baltica, which rotated into the natural dry zone along the Tropic of Capricorn. In these near-deserts, the Old Red Sandstone sedimentary beds formed, made red by the oxidized iron (hematite) characteristic of drought conditions. Near the equator Pangaea began to consolidate from the plates containing North America and Europe, further raising the northern Appalachian Mountains and forming the Caledonian Mountains in Great Britain and Scandinavia. The southern continents remained tied together in the supercontinent of Gondwana. The remainder of modern Eurasia lay in the Northern Hemisphere. Sea levels were high worldwide, and much of the land lay submerged under shallow seas. The deep, enormous Panthalassa (the "universal ocean") covered the rest of the planet. Other minor oceans were Paleo-Tethys, Proto-Tethys, Rheic Ocean and Ural Ocean (which was closed during the collision with Siberia and Baltica).

4. The continent Euramerica was formed by the collision of Laurentia and Baltica.
5. Laurasia rotated into the natural dry zone along the Tropic of Capricorn during the Devonian period.
6. Old Red Sandstone sedimentary beds were formed due to drought conditions in the near-deserts of Euramerica.
7. The southern continents remained in the supercontinent of Gondwana during the Devonian period.
8. Pangaea began to consolidate from the plates containing North America and Europe during the Devonian period.
9. The northern Appalachian Mountains and Caledonian Mountains were formed due to tectonic activity in the Devonian period.
10. The southern continents remained tied together in the supercontinent of Gondwana during the Devonian period.
11. Modern Eurasia lay in the Northern Hemisphere during the Devonian period.
12. Sea levels were high worldwide during the Devonian period.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and produce a very long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
Geological history of Earth
The Devonian spanned roughly from 419 to 359 Ma. The period was a time of great tectonic activity, as Laurasia and Gondwana drew closer together. The continent Euramerica (or Laurussia) was created in the early Devonian by the collision of Laurentia and Baltica, which rotated into the natural dry zone along the Tropic of Capricorn. In these near-deserts, the Old Red Sandstone sedimentary beds formed, made red by the oxidized iron (hematite) characteristic of drought conditions. Near the equator Pangaea began to consolidate from the plates containing North America and Europe, further raising the northern Appalachian Mountains and forming the Caledonian Mountains in Great Britain and Scandinavia. The southern continents remained tied together in the supercontinent of Gondwana. The remainder of modern Eurasia lay in the Northern Hemisphere. Sea levels were high worldwide, and much of the land lay submerged under shallow seas. The deep, enormous Panthalassa (the "universal ocean") covered the rest of the planet. Other minor oceans were Paleo-Tethys, Proto-Tethys, Rheic Ocean and Ural Ocean (which was closed during the collision with Siberia and Baltica).

Implications:

articles.title: Electric motor
articles.context: Stepper motors were and still are often used in computer printers, optical scanners, and digital photocopiers to move the optical scanning element, the print head carriage (of dot matrix and inkjet printers), and the platen or feed rollers. Likewise, many computer plotters (which since the early 1990s have been replaced with large-format inkjet and laser printers) used rotary stepper motors for pen and platen movement; the typical alternatives here were either linear stepper motors or servomotors with closed-loop analog control systems.

articles.title: Napoleon
articles.context: Two days after the marriage, Bonaparte left Paris to take command of the Army of Italy. He immediately went on the offensive, hoping to defeat the forces of Piedmont before their Austrian allies could intervene. In a series of rapid victories during the Montenotte Campaign, he knocked Piedmont out of the war in two weeks. The French then focused on the Austrians for the remainder of the war, the highlight of which became the protracted struggle for Mantua. The Austrians launched a series of offensives against the French to break the siege, but Napoleon defeated every relief effort, scoring notable victories at the battles of Castiglione, Bassano, Arcole, and Rivoli. The decisive French triumph at Rivoli in January 1797 led to the collapse of the Austrian position in Italy. At Rivoli, the Austrians lost up to 14,000 men while the French lost about 5,000.

Napoleon

articles.title: Mary (mother of Jesus)
articles.context: Differences in feasts may also originate from doctrinal issuesâ€”the Feast of the Assumption is such an example. Given that there is no agreement among all Christians on the circumstances of the death, Dormition or Assumption of Mary, the feast of assumption is celebrated among some denominations and not others.  While the Catholic Church celebrates the Feast of the Assumption on August 15, some Eastern Catholics celebrate it as Dormition of the Theotokos, and may do so on August 28, if they follow the Julian calendar. The Eastern Orthodox also celebrate it as the Dormition of the Theotokos, one of their 12 Great Feasts. Protestants do not celebrate this, or any other Marian feasts.

articles.title: United States presidential election, 2004
articles.context: Just eight months into his presidency, the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001 suddenly transformed Bush into a wartime president. Bush's approval ratings surged to near 90%. Within a month, the forces of a coalition led by the United States entered Afghanistan, which had been sheltering Osama bin Laden, suspected mastermind of the September 11 attacks. By December, the Taliban had been removed as rulers of Kabul, although a long and ongoing reconstruction would follow, severely hampered by ongoing turmoil and violence within the country.

articles.title: Gregorian calendar
articles.context: In addition to the change in the mean length of the calendar year from 365.25 days (365 days 6 hours) to 365.2425 days (365 days 5 hours 49 minutes 12 seconds), a reduction of 10 minutes 48 seconds per year, the Gregorian calendar reform also dealt with the accumulated difference between these lengths. The canonical Easter tables were devised at the end of the third century, when the vernal equinox fell either on 20 March or 21 March depending on the year's position in the leap year cycle. As the rule was that the full moon preceding Easter was not to precede the equinox the equinox was fixed at 21 March for computational purposes and the earliest date for Easter was fixed at 22 March. The Gregorian calendar reproduced these conditions by removing ten days.

completions.text:
1. The Gregorian calendar introduced a new system to regulate the mean length of the calendar year, reducing it from 365.25 days to 365.2425 days.
2. This change resulted in a reduction of 10 minutes 48 seconds per year.
3. The Gregorian calendar reform addressed the accumulated difference between the original mean length of the calendar year and the actual length of the solar year.
4. The canonical Easter tables were devised at the end of the third century, with the vernal equinox falling on either 20 March or 21 March.
5. The rule for Easter's full moon not to precede the equinox established the fixed equinox date of 21 March for computational purposes.
6. This fixed equinox date resulted in Easter's earliest possible date being 22 March.
7. The Gregorian calendar reproduced these conditions by eliminating ten days from the calendar.

8. The Gregorian calendar reform brought the calendar year closer in alignment with the solar year, which has implications for the consistent occurrence of the seasons.
9. It is essential to note that the change in the calendar year's length was implemented to account for the calendar slowly drifting out of alignment with the Earth's orbit around the sun.
10. This adjustment helps to prevent future years from progressively changing the timing of the seasons.
11. The reform introduced an additional complexity to the leap year system, as the Gregorian calendar specifies that century years must be divisible by 400 to be leap years, making 365.2425 days more accurate than previous standards.
12. The adjustments made to the calendar year length have implications for historical and astronomical events that span multiple years.
13. The correction in the Gregorian calendar required adjusting the days on which certain historical events occurred.
14. The changes in the calendar system have implications for people's lives and activities that are tied to the Gregorian calendar.

16. The reform has implications for individuals with religious observances, as Easter and other Christian festivals are based on the Gregorian calendar.
17. The adjustments to the calendar year length have implications for celestial navigation and astronomical events, such as eclipses, which depend on precise calculations of the solar year.
18. The modifications to the calendar have implications for historical records, as they make it easier to accurately date events based on the solar year.
19. The changes in the calendar year length have implications for agricultural practices, as the Gregorian calendar is used in most agricultural societies worldwide.
20. The adjustment in the Gregorian calendar has implications for modern-day timekeeping, as it is the foundation for our current method of measuring time.
21. The adoption of the Gregorian calendar requires education and awareness among individuals, as it introduces new ways of understanding and referring to dates and years.
22. The introduction of the Gregorian calendar impacted the way historians and astronomers analyze historical and astronomical events over long periods.
23. The changes in the calendar year length have implications for industries that rely on the Gregorian calendar, such as publishing and copyright laws.
24. The Gregorian calendar reform was not immediately adopted by all countries, leading to varying adoption dates and inconsistencies in dates across different regions.
25. The implications of the Gregorian calendar reform extend beyond the calendar system and have influenced various fields, including mathematics, physics, and computer science.
26. The adoption of the Gregorian calendar had societal implications, as it impacted how people organized their lives around dates and calendars.
27. The Gregorian calendar reform led to the establishment of the ISO 8601 standard, which specifies that the Gregorian calendar is the only valid calendar for international use.
28. The changes in the Gregorian calendar have implications for genealogy and family history research, as it requires adjustments in dates and calculations to accurately record family events.
29. The adjustments in the calendar year length have implications for the study of history, as they help to establish accurate timelines for historical events.
30. The Gregorian calendar reform highlights the importance of continuously revising and improving calendar systems to better align with the natural world and maintain accuracy over time.

articles.title: House music
articles.context: Early house music was generally dance-based music characterized by repetitive 4/4 beats, rhythms mainly provided by drum machines, off-beat hi-hat cymbals, and synthesized basslines. While house displayed several characteristics similar to disco music, it was more electronic and minimalistic, and the repetitive rhythm of house was more important than the song itself. House music in the 2010s, while keeping several of these core elements, notably the prominent kick drum on every beat, varies widely in style and influence, ranging from the soulful and atmospheric deep house to the more minimalistic microhouse. House music has also fused with several other genres creating fusion subgenres, such as euro house, tech house, electro house and jump house.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and produce a very long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
House music
Early house music was generally dance-based music characterized by repetitive 4/4 beats, rhythms mainly provided by drum machines, off-beat hi-hat cymbals, and synthesized basslines. While house displayed several characteristics similar to disco music, it was more electronic and minimalistic, and the repetitive rhythm of house was more important than the song itself. House music in the 2010s, while keeping several of these core elements, notably the prominent kick drum on every beat, varies widely in style and influence, ranging from the soulful and atmospheric deep house to the more minimalistic microhouse. House music has also fused with several other genres creating fusion subgenres, such as euro house, tech house, electro house and jump house.

articles.context: Near the northern Greek borders there are also some Slavicâ€“speaking groups, locally known as Slavomacedonian-speaking, most of whose members identify ethnically as Greeks. Their dialects can be linguistically classified as forms of either Macedonian Slavic or Bulgarian. The Jewish community in Greece traditionally spoke Ladino (Judeo-Spanish), today maintained only by a few thousand speakers. Other notable minority languages include Armenian, Georgian, and the Greco-Turkic dialect spoken by the Urums, a community of Caucasus Greeks from the Tsalka region of central Georgia and ethnic Greeks from southeastern Ukraine who arrived in mainly Northern Greece as economic migrants in the 1990s.

articles.title: Sexual orientation
articles.context: Most definitions of sexual orientation include a psychological component, such as the direction of an individual's erotic desires, or a behavioral component, which focuses on the sex of the individual's sexual partner/s. Some people prefer simply to follow an individual's self-definition or identity. Scientific and professional understanding is that "the core attractions that form the basis for adult sexual orientation typically emerge between middle childhood and early adolescence". Sexual orientation differs from sexual identity in that it encompasses relationships with others, while sexual identity is a concept of self.

completions.text:

2. The term "sexual orientation" includes various dimensions of an individual's life, including their sexual attractions, behaviors, and personal identity.
3. The majority of definitions of sexual orientation focus on the direction of an individual's erotic desires and the sex of their partners, as well as the individual's self-perception or identity.
4. A person's self-definition of their sexual orientation is an important factor to consider when understanding their sexual identity, particularly for people who may not fit neatly into traditional categories.
5. A person's sexual orientation may not always align with their biological sex, as the core attractions that form the basis for sexual orientation typically emerge in early adolescence.
6. The scientific and professional understanding of sexual orientation suggests that sexual attraction typically emerges between middle childhood and early adolescence.
7. People's sexual orientation is a complex and dynamic aspect of their identity, and may change or evolve over time, as individuals' desires and experiences change.
8. Self-identification can vary greatly between individuals, and people may identify differently within different communities or cultures, which can also impact their sexual identity.
9. Understanding the psychology of sexual orientation is important for healthcare providers and professionals who work with individuals who may be struggling with their sexual orientation or identity.
10. Social stigma and negative attitudes towards non-heterosexual orientations can have a significant impact on an individual's sense of self, identity, and overall well-being, making it important to support and validate people's experiences and self-identifications.

Passage:
Under few circumstances does the U.S. government intervene in marital matters at the state level. When determining a child's best interests, courts will consider the child's religious, physical, moral, and emotional needs. These determine whether the child will be permitted to keep the original surname, change it, or create a hybrid name. In nearly half the states, a child born with one surname may take the other parent's surname or a combination of the parents' surnames upon divorce or separation. Some states even allow a child to keep his or her birth surname after the divorce or separation, such as Mississippi, Colorado, and Montana. Some surnames, such as "Newland" and "Coteson," have not been legal in the United States since the beginning of the 20th century.

articles.title: Franco-Prussian War
articles.context: With the defeat of Marshal Bazaine's Army of the Rhine at Gravelotte, the French were forced to retire to Metz, where they were besieged by over 150,000 Prussian troops of the First and Second Armies. Napoleon III and MacMahon formed the new French Army of ChÃ¢lons, to march on to Metz to rescue Bazaine. Napoleon III personally led the army with Marshal MacMahon in attendance. The Army of ChÃ¢lons marched northeast towards the Belgian border to avoid the Prussians before striking south to link up with Bazaine. The Prussians, under the command of Field Marshal Count Helmuth von Moltke, took advantage of this maneuver to catch the French in a pincer grip. He left the Prussian First and Second Armies besieging Metz, except three corps detached to form the Army of the Meuse under the Crown Prince of Saxony. With this army and the Prussian Third Army, Moltke marched northward and caught up with the French at Beaumont on 30 August. After a sharp fight in which they lost 5,000 men and 40 cannons, the French withdrew toward Sedan. Having reformed in the town, the Army of ChÃ¢lons was immediately isolated by the converging Prussian armies. Napoleon III ordered the army to break out of the encirclement immediately. With MacMahon wounded on the previous day, General Auguste Ducrot took command of the French troops in the field.

articles.title: Hunter-gatherer
articles.context: Hunter-gatherer societies manifest significant variability, depending on climate zone/life zone, available technology and societal structure. Archaeologists examine hunter-gatherer tool kits to measure variability across different groups. Collard et al. (2005) found temperature to be the only statistically significant factor to impact hunter-gatherer tool kits. Using temperature as a proxy for risk, Collard et al.'s results suggest that environments with extreme temperatures pose a threat to hunter-gatherer systems significant enough to warrant increased variability of tools. These results support Torrence's (1989) theory that risk of failure is indeed the most important factor in determining the structure of hunter-gatherer toolkits.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and produce a very long list of implications derived directly or indirectly from the content.

Passage:
Hunter-gatherer
Hunter-gatherer societies manifest significant variability, depending on climate zone/life zone, available technology and societal structure. Archaeologists examine hunter-gatherer tool kits to measure variability across different groups. Collard et al. (2005) found temperature to be the only statistically significant factor to impact hunter-gatherer tool kits. Using temperature as a proxy for risk, Collard et al.'s results suggest that environments with extreme temperatures pose a threat to hunter-gatherer systems significant enough to warrant increased variability of tools. These results support Torrence's (1989) theory that risk of failure is indeed the most important factor in determining the structure of hunter-gatherer toolkits.
